message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described symptoms and image are consistent with vitiligo, which is typically caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. Options B, C, and D are not associated with vitiligo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s skin findings suggest vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune melanocyte destruction. Option B (increased mTOR signalling) and option C (Mycobacterium leprae infection) are not associated with vitiligo. Option D (postinflammatory depigmentation) is a possible differential diagnosis but is less likely given the lack of redness, itchiness or pain in the lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description matches that of vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune melanocyte destruction. Increased mTOR signalling is related to disorders such as tuberous sclerosis complex and sporadic lymphangioleiomyomatosis. Mycobacterium leprae infection causes leprosy. Postinflammatory depigmentation occurs after an inflammatory skin condition.

We refer to DermNet NZ for help. The skin findings are consistent with vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. Increased mTOR signaling is associated with conditions such as tuberous sclerosis, but does not cause vitiligo. Mycobacterium leprae infection can cause depigmented lesions, but the presentation in this case is not consistent with leprosy. Postinflammatory depigmentation occurs after an inflammatory skin condition, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of multiple depigmented patches suggests vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. Options B and C are incorrect as they do not cause depigmentation, and option D is incorrect as there is no history of inflammation or injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The depigmented lesions suggest vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. None of the other options are consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description and appearance of the skin lesions are consistent with vitiligo, which is typically caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. Increased mTOR signaling is associated with conditions such as tuberous sclerosis and lymphangioleiomyomatosis. Mycobacterium leprae infection can cause depigmented patches, but this presentation is not typical. Postinflammatory depigmentation occurs after dermatitis or other skin inflammation, which is not evident in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and images suggest vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune melanocyte destruction. Increased mTOR signalling is associated with tuberous sclerosis complex and other genetic disorders. Mycobacterium leprae infection leads to leprosy, which causes nodules and thickened skin, but not depigmented lesions. Postinflammatory depigmentation occurs after inflammation or trauma to the skin, but the patient reports no associated symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The depigmentation of the skin suggests vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune melanocyte destruction. The other options are not associated with depigmentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The depigmented lesions on the trunk, thighs, hands, feet, and around the mouth suggest vitiligo, which is an autoimmune disease where the body attacks melanocytes, resulting in depigmentation of the skin. Increased mTOR signalling and Mycobacterium leprae infection are not associated with depigmentation of the skin. Postinflammatory depigmentation is a possible cause, but the gradual increase in size over the past 2 years suggests otherwise.
